discussion.content: Im wondering why BYOD isn't on this list?
SLA could also mean Service Lever Agreement

Stands for "Acceptable Use Policy." An AUP is list of rules you must follow in order to use a website or Internet service. It is similar to a software license agreement (SLA), but is used specifically for Internet services.

comments.content: SLA - Service level agreement - ensured quality
I assume that you have to agree to not use the guest Wi-Fi for anything malicious... Typically through a portal

questions.question_text: Employees want the ability to use personal devices on the guest network while working out at the company gym. In order to meet the request, which of the following policies requires employee adherence?
Which of the following BEST describes the BGP routing protocol?

discussion.content: How to remember Routing protocols (or how so i did at least) and i suggest you draw this out, interior and exterior (inside and outside). Let's start with the exterior as there is only 1 BGP hybrid (i think of this a something different compared to the other routing protocols, as if its a "god" or a better than the rest). Moving on to the interior, you have Distance Vector and Link State, DV (Distance Vector) has RIPv1, RIPv2, IGRP and EIGRP, LS (Link State) has 2 OSPF and IS-IS. (now how do i remember this? ever notice how all have the distance vectors have the 3 letters in all of them "R" "I" "P" in them, maybe in a different order and the others [OSPF and IS-IS] do not which make them Link State)
BGP is a distance vector routing protocol. EIRGP is a hybrid.

comments.content: No its not, its hybrid
Professor Messer says BGP is hybrid. Going with him

discussion.content: its hybrid .its considered hybrid coz it contains link state and distance vector .confirmed given answer is correct
BGP: EGP, path-vector, classless protocol. Comptia point of view BGP(Border Gateway Protocol) is hybrid Protocol.
comptia study guide says: BGP is not a pure distance vector... but uses a hybrid approach... is more usually classed as a path routing vector

Mike Meyers says BGP is technically a path vector routing protocol, but then says this...
"Exam Tip: The CompTIA Network+ objectives list BGP as a hybrid routing protocol. Read the question carefully and if BGP is your only answer as hybrid, take it." Mike Meyers, Network+, page 243

After seeing https://www.professormesser.com/network-plus/n10-007/dynamic-routing-protocols/
I have changed my mind, it is hybrid protocol.
Correct answer is B. hybrid.

The correct answer is A.
An example of a hybrid routing protocol would be something like EIGRP.
https://www.professormesser.com/network-plus/n10-006/link-state-distance-vector-and-hybrid-routing-protocols-2/

I have seen many times a incorrected answer is upvoted most lol
EIGRP/BGP both are Hybrid, it's clearly on the page303 of book Net+

IMO, option "A" is the correct answer.

https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/difference-between-eigrp-and-bgp/?ref=rp

comments.content: Right!? I feel like some people dont read the books and try only using these questions to pass the actual exam.

discussion.content: Read a book guys! the amount of complain and lack of question understanding in this site is tremendous! geez! BGP is hybrid routing protocol in fact it is a path vector routing protocol!

BGP
The Border Gateway Protocol is considered a hybrid protocol in the CompTIA objectives as it employs elements of both Link-state and distance-vector protocols. Technically it is classified as an advanced protocol.

https://www.certblaster.com/network-plus-n10-007-examnotes-sub-objective-1-3-routing-and-switching-part-2-of-3/#:~:text=Hybrid-,BGP,classified%20as%20an%20advanced%20protocol.

The Border Gateway Protocol is considered a hybrid protocol in the CompTIA objectives as it employs elements of both Link-state and distance-vector protocols. Technically it is classified as an advanced protocol.

According to Anthony Sequeira, CCIE No. 15626 (Network+ N10-007), 'some literature classifies BGP as a distance- vector routing protocol, it can more accurately be described as a path- vector routing protocol'.
According to Mike Meyers the BGP is a hybrid model and EIRGP is listed a distance vector for CompTIA exam.
According to certblaster: "The Border Gateway Protocol is considered a hybrid protocol in the CompTIA objectives as it employs elements of both Link-state and distance-vector protocols."

According to the official Comptia Network+ Guide : BGP is not a pure distance-vector algorithm but uses a hybrid approach. In fact, BGP is more usually classed a path vector routing protocol. A very confusion question.
BGP is Border Gateway Protocol. Classified as a Path Vector Protocol but is sometimes also classed as a Distance Vector Routing Protocol.

questions.question_text:
A customer is reporting difficulty connecting some devices after replacing a wireless router with a new wireless 802.11ac router. The SSID, encryption and password are the same as the previous router. A technician goes on-site and notices the devices that are no longer connecting appear to be several years ago.
Which of the following is MOST likely the problem?

comments.content: Great explanation! thanks!

discussion.content: Letter D cause 802.11ac utilizes 5 GHz and since it is already 'several' years. The devices that are connected to the replaced WAP are probably 802.11b/g compliant devices. cheers!

choices.B: there is a security type mismatch.
choices.A: the password needs to be re-entered.

discussion.content:
Question states that multiple devices are having issues with network connectivity: Workstation C will never communicate properly because it will always have the APIPA address. DHCP client on the main network to the left of Router B now have 2 DHCP servers handing out different scope ip configs that will result in occasional loss of connectivity for multiple client devices.
30 years of IT experience. Last 10 years teaching around 50 classes/yr regarding networking and cybersecurity. Slowly but surely vetting all these questions for correctness. Only up through the first 200. Hope that this helps!

comments.content: i see why this is right but is that the only problem in this network

To add to my comment, Laptop 1 got its IP from Server 2 via WAP2 and SwitchD and Server2 so that's not a problem with "A wireless client is unable to associate to the AP"
Laptop1 gets its IP from Server 2 and Laptop 2 gets its IP from Server1. Tricky image are you'd think Laptop 1 belongs to Server 1, and Laptop2 belongs to Server2...

and one more point to prove my point it is the STP on the switches doing the problem. The question says "Multiple users are reporting that they are unable to access the network." so even with multiple DHCP scopes, the users would still get an IP, even if "duplicate IP found on network" error shows it means connections are happening, but the question says they unable to access the network.

The only problem I see with your answer AFitGuy is you are 'assuming' the routers are giving out DHCP addresses. What basis do you have? If you have a DHCP server, you don't have a router doing this as well. Secondly none of the answers hint at DHCP clashes, just DHCP addy's running out, so sorry I have to disagree with your answer. BTW I don't like "G" answer either as it says 'multiple devices' which one would think it being a switch issue. So E would be the only logical one as these are two sites, ie: Internet? They don't give the far side IPs of the routers (like you said, correctness is an issue).
So is it G still or C

discussion.content: Which is the wireless client that can’t access the AP please?

My take is that Site A/ Workstation C is not getting an IP because SOHO router 1's connection is being blocked by STP on Switch B.
Part 1 answer = Tick SOHO router 1
Part 2 answer = E. STP has disabled some of the ports on the switch.

The answer also could be the simplest - ACL issues or #B. Question says multiple users are unable to access the network, which might mean they have proper IP address, but can't connect to the other site, or network due to ACL's.

comments.content: another thought - could it be the WAN/LAN ports are reversed on Router A or B? But the question doesn't give the far side IPs of the routers for some stupid reason.

after long thought, it isn't STP on the switch, disregard my post. Just the idea of multiple users is throwing me. However is SOHO1 is giving out IP's because it has the WAN/LAN mixed up, it could be broadcasting out 172.30.10.x IPs to WSA, B, and Laptop2 and cause conflicts to DHCP1 (172.30.0.x) until they renew?

discussion.content: My answer would be E that "STP had disabled some of the ports on the switch" to affect "multiple users". The network diagram is fine (except WStn C) as the wireless laptops are getting the proper IP from the DHCP's. Laptop2 gets its IP from Server1 (172.30.0.x) and Laptop1 gets its IP from Server2 (172.16.0.x).
I found a helpful explanation of this problem here: https://wyzguyscybersecurity.com/reference-desk/network-n10-007-performance-based-questions-pbq/

comments.content: I don't agree (albeit thanks to whoever did drew it out) as the wireless devices do have the proper IP address associated with the DHCP server they are getting it from. As in Laptop 2 has 172.30.0.12 from DHCP1 (scope:172.30.0.10-250) and Laptop 1 gets its IP (172.16.0.220) from DHCP2 (scope 172.16.0.10-250)
sorry i keep adding, but yes the SOHO Router1 isn't giving out DHCP so WorkstationC gets an APIPA, but that's not answering the point about multiple users not connecting, just one.
Thanks

discussion.content:
Somewhere, there is a wireless client that is unable to associate to the AP. This lack of association is causing multiple clients to have connectivity issues. (1) Which wireless client isn't connecting to the AP and (2) how is that issue causing problems for "multiple clients"?

I don't understand the answer. I don't understand how to answer Part 1 either.
I had 5 PBQs and thank God this wasn't one of them.
Long story short, workstation C is the problem.

comments.content: SOHO Router1 isn't giving out IP addresses, so WSC comes up with APIPA 169.254.x.x so that is the one answer to the question. The other is maybe the WAN link on SOHO Router 1 is backwards (explains why WS-C isn't getting an IP), but doesn't explain multiple users having issues. So the other option is ACL or STP issue on Site A switch.

discussion.content: Can anyone explain for the part 1, what is the correct answer?

So all the addresses except for Workstation G and F in Site B are receiving an ip address from DHCP Server 2 scope of 172.16.0.0/24. Workstations G and F are getting their ip address from SOHO Router 2's DHCP scope of 172.16.10.0/24 on the LAN side of that router. Look at the ip addressing scheme: Every device connected to Router A's righthand interface has the first three octets of 172.16.0, and the network connected to the top interface of SOHO Router 2 has ips like this 172.16.10.
Site A was designed to use the same ip addressing scheme. The network on the lefthand-side of Router B is being assigned ip addresses from DHCP Server 1 with a scope of 172.30.0.0/24. That main network has the 3rd octet set to "0" just like Site B's main network.

The idea was to use SOHO Router 1 in Site A just like they used SOHO Router 2 in Site B. SOHO routers can provide DHCP addresses to their LAN interface network only. The WAN interface could set to be a DHCP client if we were connecting to an ISP. But all these router interfaces are connected to internal subnets, except for the blue WAN link between Router B and Router A. The diagram doesn't even give us ip addressing info for that link. In this case, both SOHO Routers' LAN and WAN interface's ip addresses and masks would be statically configured with the LAN interface providing DHCP service to the LAN side only.

comments.content: only problem with the SOHO router is the question being multiple users with the problem, WS-C is the only one affected. However, SOHO1 can't see anyone else due to its IP being 172.30.10.1 and everyone else is 172.30.0.x,

I think you have the right answer! Nothing else seems to work. It wouldn't be a driver issue for the WS as it got an IP even if 169.254, and all the wireless devices have the right IP addresses to the DHCP server it is connected to.

discussion.content: The secret to this question is why does Workstation C have APIPA (169.254.200.67). SOHO Router 1 has its interfaces plugged into the wrong network segments. The correct answer is SOHO Router 1 should be checked in Part 1, and "D" The WAN/LAN ports are reversed on the router should be selected in Part 2.

comments.content: I have to disagree with the NIC driver issue, if this was the case then APIPA wouldn't work. APIPA works when the computer can't get an IP from a DHCP service, so it will self assign one and thereby be able to talk to others on the same network, meaning the driver is working.

discussion.content:
Another terrible question from CompTia. Assuming Part A and Part B are related (a stretch for CompTia I know) i.e. checkmark the problem device then identify the reason.
Workstation C has an APIPA address which is the symtom of the problem. What can cause this; IP not refreshed, Ethernet cable damaged, Nic goes down, DHCP server issues. Many many reasons. 
Therefore we must look to part 2 for the possible answers and start eliminating. 
C or F are most likely to be consistent with APIPA. C is not the issue as there are no issue with available addresses in the scope. So it must be F - Nic driver is not installed.

My answer = Workstation C, NIC driver not installed.

Caveat
Issue is presenting in Site A. DHCP Server 2 does have incorrect gateway (typo possibly) but no issues are presenting in Site B
This was my question ONE today, had NO idea, even the other two were just as bad so back to drawing board

comments.content: Do you remember the other 2?

discussion.content:
Part 1: Soho Router 1. DHCP is not enabled, therefore workstation C has APIPA address. 
Part 2: G. A wireless client is unable to associate to the AP.
how is G the answer to part 2 of this?

Well well well, I guess and just a guess. The reason why all of this devices can't go outside the network because they were configured in to private IP address. All subnet mask are correct if they are under classless /24 route.

comments.content: That isn't an issue if they have the same IP as they are in different Sites, or have to cross a router. think NATing.

discussion.content: Part 1- DHCP server 2 has the same ip address of DHCP server 1. Also soho router 1 does not have DHCP enabled on it so that is why Workstation C has a APIPA address

There are many of devices has problem. 
Station A:
workstation C : Apipa Address 

Station B:
Workstation D, E, Laptop1 All has wrong Default gateway assigned to them. 
DHCP 2: is on a different subnet 172.30.0.5 Needs a sub net range of 172.16.10.0.1-255

comments.content: You mentioned F, as in bad NIC driver? How would a bad NIC driver work in getting an IP address?

There is nothing wrong with WS F and WS G IP addresses because they are behind SOHO router2 that routes packets from 172.16.10.0/24 net to 172.16.0.0/24 net and vice versa. There seem to be a typo in DHCP srv2 IP address (30 instead of 16). WS C indicates that there is an Ethernet connection problem. I disagree with Wireless AP answer because both laptop2 and WS B are getting proper host and gateway IP addresses in 172.30.0.0/24 net from DHCP1. Correct answer should be focused on Ethernet connection issues such as NIC driver, bad NIC, bad cable or connector, disabled switch port, etc. In this case, F is correct answer.

Ok, let me add some here too>>
Site A: 
WS C- APIPA address, no Gateway assigned.

Site B:
DHCP2 IP address is same as 1st one- which is wrong considering that it is not even same subnet, so 172.30.0.5 should kind of become 172.16.0.5 for 2nd DHCP.
Laptop 1, WS D, WS E - I see no problem with it, enlight me if I am wrong, where it is and why their def gateway is wrong?.
WS F and WS G have wrong IP: 172.16.10.43 & 172.16.10.1 (10 instead of 0, which is separate subnet) respectively and seem have their SOHO router as Gateway instead Router B.
Have I missed anything?
Oh yeah- regarding wireless devices- i would separate them, but here they all are on respectively same subnet as the rest of their site. well VLAN will do the job then.

For Part 1, I agree with your answer for Site A, Workstation C (APIPA address) as well as your answer for Site B, DHCP2 (needs an IP address that's within the DHCP Scope of 172.16.0.1-255 because its Gateway is 172.16.0.1). However, I disagree with your answer for Site B, Workstation D, Workstation E, and Laptop 1. The Default Gateway for these should all be 172.16.0.1 (Router A).
DHCP Server 2 has wrong IP address. The default gateway is 172.16.0.1 and the IP address is 172.30.0.5. Need to assign DHCP server an IP address in the 172.16.0.0/24 network.
While I agree the DHCP2 is on wrong subnet, how'd the WS-D&E and Laptop1 get their IP addy's?
Doesn't matter if it has the wrong IP because DHCP requests are broadcasts, unless you are using a DHCP relay.

4. Residual DHCP Leases: If DHCP Server 2 was previously configured correctly and then changed, the computers might still be using their old IP addresses. DHCP leases often last for days or even weeks, so the computers could still have valid IP addresses from before DHCP Server 2 was reconfigured.
Other options are: Static IP Addresses, which is not the case here, SOHO Router 2, which might be correct only in the case of Workstation F and G, and last possibility: Another DHCP Server, which we do not see in this shitty diagram.

discussion.content: What’s the answer of part 1?

choices.F: The NIC driver is not installed.
choices.D: WAN and LAN ports are reversed on the router.
choices.G: A wireless client is unable to associate to the AP.
choices.B: The site-to-site router was configured with the incorrect ACL.
choices.A: Workstation(s) are plugged into switch ports configured with half duplex.
choices.E: STP has disabled some of the ports on the switch.
choices.C: The DHCP server scope is full and is not providing IP addresses.

comments.content: How are you going to get the site survey from several different business in an office complex though?

discussion.content: The site survey will allow us to see the overlap of networks, being able to pinpoint where the interference is coming from.

This is from Mike Meyer's book:
Installing and configuring a Wi-Fi network requires a number of
discrete steps. You should start with a site survey to determine any
obstacles (existing wireless, interference, and so on) you need to
overcome and to determine the best location for your access points.

So he said a site survey will let you determine if there is interference, so the answer is correct.
I think the real answer is check with a spectrum analyzer which can see the other networks signals.
I feel like wardriving would be a part of the survey right?

comments.content:
War driving is a "survey" conducted in a vehicle. You are searching for wireless networks, typically unsecured WLANs using a laptop or smartphone. You can find a list of software used to do this here. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wardriving

discussion.content: site survey is correct
Steve says it's A
Why is not the answer E?

comments.content: because bandwidth deals with the AMOUNT OF DATA TRANSMITTED over an internet connection at a given time. So a bandwidth test would just be checking the upload/download times of the network. I thought it was E too.

questions.question_text:
A network technician is troubleshooting wireless network issues in a crowded office complex and suspects there is interference from nearby wireless networks.
Which of the following should the technician perform to discover possible interference?
